properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow Saturday night and Sunday in Resolute. Strong winds and falling snow will combine to reduce the visibility in blowing snow by Saturday afternoon. By the evening hours visibility may degrade to below 400 m bringing blizzard conditions to the area. Poor visibility will persist through the night and much of Sunday. This alert may be upgraded to a blizzard warning as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-06T20:51:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-06T04:52:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4235669318.2021
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with visibilities below 400 m will continue this morning. Conditions will improve later this morning when winds begin to ease. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls continue this morning. What: Snow squalls. Reduced visibilities in heavy snow with additional amounts up to 5 cm this morning, particularly over higher terrain. Where: Areas south of Georgian Bay. When: This morning. Discussion: Lake effect snow will continue this morning and weaken around the noon hour. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-06T20:59:48-00:00

Area: Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop tonight. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: overnight tonight through Sunday night. Total snowfall accumulations: 5 to 15 cm. Remarks: strong southwesterly winds will combine with periodic snow squalls to produce reduced visibility in blowing snow. Conditions favourable for snow squalls will diminish by Monday morning once the winds weaken and veer to the northwest. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-07T11:27:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-06T19:28:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0574918177.2021

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY CONTINUED FOR VERNON (March 5, 2021 - Vernon) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory issued on March 3, 2021 for Vernon due to high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is a concern for pregnant women, infants, and older adults, as well as, individuals with conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, diabetes or respiratory infections such as COVID-19. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-07T04:28:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-06T12:29:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2958149661.2021
Area: North Okanagan

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility, as low as 400 m, in snow and blowing snow tonight. Strengthening winds will begin to reduce the visibility in blowing snow this afternoon. By this evening snow will begin to fall and will drop the visibility to below 400 m bringing blizzard conditions to the area. Poor visibility will persist through the night and much of Sunday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions expected across most of the Kivalliq region this weekend. As a low pressure system approaches from the Northwest Territories, an area of snow and strong southerly winds gusting from 60 to 80 km/h will produce blizzard conditions starting this morning in a few communities. Conditions will deteriorate from west to east across the area, firstly in Baker Lake and Arviat this morning before affecting the communities of Rankin Inlet and Chesterfield Inlet this evening. Finally, further to the north and east in Naujaat, conditions will begin to worsen late this evening. Visibilities should begin to improve later tonight in Baker Lake and Arviat but will likely remain poor in the remaining coastal communities and in Naujaat until Sunday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-07T07:36:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-06T15:37:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2522320732.2021
Area: Baker Lake, Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet, Naujaat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are possible Sunday in Coral Harbour. As a low pressure system approaches the Kivalliq region from the Northwest Territories today, an area of snow and strong southerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h may produce blizzard conditions in Coral Harbour beginning Sunday afternoon. If a blizzard occurs, visibilities should improve by Monday morning. As the event draws near, this bulletin will either be upgraded to a blizzard warning or ended outright if blizzard conditions are no longer expected. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
